si0004.svg svg 6374 ALTIMG APCATA 120329 120329 S0926-860X(25)00230-3 10.1016/j.apcata.2025.120329 Elsevier B.V. Fig. 1 Effect of different B2O3 loading content. The catalytic tests were conducted at 620 °C with a C3H8/O2 molar ratio of 3:2, using 2 g of catalyst, WHSV = 3.53 gC3H8·gcat−1·h−1. The catalyst, designated as B2O3/SiO2-TiO2 (1−2), was prepared with a SiO2/TiO2 weight ratio of 1:2. Fig. 1 Fig. 2 Effect of SiO2/TiO2 ratio on catalytic performance: (a) propane conversion and (b) propylene selectivity. Reaction conditions: 620 °C, C3H8/O2 molar ratio = 3:2, catalyst weight = 2 g, WHSV = 3.53 gC3H8·gcat−1·h−1. SiO2 and TiO2 represent the single-component support materials, corresponding to pure silica and pure titania supports, respectively. Fig. 2 Fig. 3 Time-on-stream catalytic performance in ODHP at 620 °C: (a) propane and (b) oxygen conversion profiles for catalysts with varying SiO2/TiO2 ratios over 24 hours. Standard reaction conditions: C3H8/O2 = 3:2 (mole ratio), 2 g catalyst, WHSV = 3.53 gC3H8·gcat−1·h−1. Fig. 3 Fig. 4 Catalytic performance evaluation: product selectivity trends for B2O3-based catalysts with different support compositions (a) pure SiO2, (b) SiO2-TiO2 (2−1), (c) SiO2-TiO2 (1−1), (d) SiO2-TiO2 (1−2), (e) pure TiO2, and (f) total C2 + C3 olefin selectivity as a function of reaction time. Reaction conditions: 620 °C, C3H8/O2 = 3:2 (mole ratio), catalyst loading = 2 g, WHSV = 3.53 gC3H8·gcat−1·h−1. Fig. 4 Fig. 5 H2-TPR analysis: (a) effect of B2O3 loading (10–30 wt%) at constant SiO2/TiO2 ratio (1:1) and (b) influence of SiO2/TiO2 composition at fixed B2O3 content (30 wt%). High-performance B2O3/SiO2-TiO2 catalyst for propane oxidation to olefins Xiaoyu Yan Writing – review & editing Writing – original draft Validation Methodology Investigation Formal analysis Data curation Conceptualization Yuhan Sun Validation Investigation Xiaoqing Xu Investigation Jiale Xu Writing – review & editing Rui Huang Writing – review & editing Renjie Ji Writing – review & editing Chunyi Li Writing – review & editing Supervision Methodology Funding acquisition Conceptualization ⁎ State Key Laboratory of Heavy Oil Processing, China University of Petroleum, Qingdao 266580, China State Key Laboratory of Heavy Oil Processing, China University of Petroleum Qingdao 266580 China State Key Laboratory of Heavy Oil Processing, China University of Petroleum, Qingdao 266580, China ⁎ Corresponding author. Conventional mixed metal oxide catalysts for oxidative dehydrogenation of propane (ODHP) often face challenges in balancing propane conversion and olefin selectivity. In contrast, boron-containing catalysts can achieve higher selectivity for olefins. In this study, B2O3/SiO2-TiO2 catalysts were prepared via mechanical mixing and calcination, demonstrating high activity in ODHP with propylene and ethylene as primary products. At 620 °C, propane conversion reached 60.8 %, with total olefin selectivity of 70.2 %. Unlike h-BN or BOx/carrier catalysts, B2O3 was directly used as both feedstock and active component, eliminating the need for an induction period. The mixed SiO2-TiO2 carrier anchored boron species on the TiO2 surface, reducing boron loss and enhancing stability compared to pure SiO2-supported catalysts. These results highlight the potential of B2O3/SiO2-TiO2 for efficient propane oxidative dehydrogenation to olefins. Graphical Abstract Keywords Propane Oxidative dehydrogenation Propylene Ethylene Boron oxide Titanium dioxide Data availability The authors do not have permission to share data. 1 Introduction Light olefins, particularly ethylene and propylene, remain indispensable chemical feedstocks with steadily growing global demand [1–5]. While steam cracking dominates current production, its high energy intensity and substantial steam requirements motivate alternative technologies [6,7]. Propane dehydrogenation (PDH) has emerged as a viable commercial alternative, though thermodynamic limitations and rapid catalyst coking persist as significant challenges [8–10]. Our group has made notable progress in previous research on this technology [11,12]. In contrast, oxidative dehydrogenation of propane (ODHP) utilizes oxygen to overcome equilibrium constraints and operates at lower temperatures, demonstrating distinct advantages over PDH [13,14]. Catalyst design represents the central challenge for ODHP implementation. Conventional metal oxide systems, such as VOx/Al2O3, typically suffer from over-oxidation of desired products through Mars-van Krevelen mechanisms [15–19]. The breakthrough discovery of hexagonal boron nitride (h-BN) catalysts demonstrated exceptional olefin selectivity (91 %) albeit with limited conversion (14 %) [20]. Subsequent studies revealed that boron's unique oxophilicity preferentially stabilizes reaction intermediates, effectively suppressing COx formation [21,22]. Further investigations identified dynamic B-O/B-OH species as the active sites responsible for maintaining catalytic cycles [19,23–25]. Despite these advances, two critical limitations hinder practical implementation of boron-based ODHP catalysts. First, low propane conversion (< 20 % in most systems) necessitates extensive gas recycling. Second, H2O generated during reaction induces irreversible boron leaching through boric acid formation [26–29]. Recent stabilization strategies, including zeolite-confined boron sites [26,30] and h-BN⊃In2O3 composites [27], have improved durability but often require complex synthesis methods while maintaining the fundamental activity-stability trade-off. In this context, we report a mechanically mixed B2O3/SiO2-TiO2 catalyst that simultaneously addresses these problems. Through controlled optimization of the support structure, we achieve 60.8 % propane conversion with 70.2 % olefin selectivity, significantly outperforming conventional h-BN systems [20,23]. The catalyst exhibits immediate activity without induction period and maintains stability through Ti-O-B bridge formation, as confirmed by spectroscopic characterization. The preparation method employs simple mechanical mixing and calcination, offering distinct advantages for scale-up compared to more complex approaches [26,27,30]. These findings demonstrate that rational support design can effectively stabilize active boron species while maintaining high catalytic performance, suggesting promising potential for industrial ODHP development. 2 Experiment 2.1 Materials In this work, boron trioxide, titanium oxide (anatase) and silica sol (containing 30 wt% silica) were purchased from Macklin Biochemical Technology Co. Ltd. (Shanghai, China). All of the chemicals used in this study were of analytical grade without further purification. 2.2 Synthesis of catalysts The catalyst samples were synthesized via a solid-state reaction method. Specifically, a predetermined amount of B2O3 was homogeneously blended with TiO2 using a planetary ball mill (Model QM-3SP2, Laibu Tech Co., Nanjing, China) at 500 rpm for 30 min. Subsequently, silica sol was introduced, followed by homogenization through manual stirring with a glass rod for 10 minutes to ensure complete mixing of all components. The resulting mixture was calcined in a muffle furnace at 650 °C for 2 h. The calcined product was then ground, pelletized, and sieved to obtain catalyst particles with a size range of 40–60 mesh. 2.3 Catalytic testing The catalytic experiments were carried out in a fixed-bed microreactor by weighing a certain weight of catalyst placed in the middle of a quartz tube (I.D. = 14 mm) with a continuous flow of gas at standard atmospheric pressure. The flow rates of propane (feed gas) and oxygen were precisely controlled by mass flow controllers, maintaining a propane-to-oxygen molar ratio of 3:2. The optimized condition was a weight hourly space velocity (WHSV) of 3.53 gC3H8·gcat−1·h−1, and the reaction was conducted at a temperature of 620 °C. The composition of the products obtained after reaction evaluation was analyzed by gas chromatography (GC). Nitrogen was used as the carrier gas for the FID channel to analyze the hydrocarbons in the product using a PLOT/Al2O3 chromatography column and FID detector. Hydrogen was employed as the carrier gas for the TCD channel, and the products were pre-separated using a Porpak Q chromatographic column with a TCD detector. The COx in the product were analyzed using a 5 A chromatographic column. The conversion of propane/oxygen, product selectivity and yield, as well as the carbon balance were calculated using Eqs. (1–4), respectively (n corresponds to the carbon number of the specific product). (1) C o n v e r s i o n ( % ) = m o l e s o f p r o p a n e o r o x y g e n c o n s u m e d i n i t i a l m o l e s o f p r o p a n e o r o x y g e n × 100 % (2) S e l e c t i v i t y ( % ) = m o l e s o f f o r m e d p r o d u c t m o l e s o f c o n s u m e d p r o p a n e × n 3 × 100 % (3) Y i e l d ( % ) = m o l e s o f f o r m e d p r o d u c t i n i t i a l m o l e s o f p r o p a n e × n 3 × 100 % (4) C a r b o n B a l a n c e ( % ) = c a r b o n m o l e s o f ( p r o d u c t s + p r o p a n e , o u t ) c a r b o n m o l e s o f p r o p a n e , i n × 100 % 2.4 Characterization of catalysts The PCA-1200 chemisorption analyser (Bioelectronics Technology Company, Beijing, China) was used to measure the surface properties of the catalyst. A 100 mg sample of the catalyst was loaded into a sample tube and pretreated at 300 °C under 40 mL/min of flowing argon gas to remove the impurities and water adsorbed on the catalyst surface. After the sample tubes were cooled to room temperature, the sample tubes were heated up to 900 °C with 30 mL/min of H2/Ar gas mixture (10 vol% hydrogen) and the hydrogen temperature-programmed reduction (H2-TPR) curves of the catalyst samples were recorded. After applying the same pretreatment, the sample tube was heated up to 100 °C, and a mixture of O2/Ar gas (oxygen content of 10 vol%) was introduced and adsorbed for 30 min, and after the adsorption, the catalyst sample was switched to argon gas purge at this temperature. Subsequently, the catalyst sample was heated to 900 °C under a helium flow of 30 mL/min to record the oxygen temperature-programmed desorption (O2-TPD) curves. XRD spectra of the catalyst samples were recorded using an Empyrean diffractometer from PANalytical, and diffraction intensities were measured using Cu Kα1,2 radiation at 40 kV and 40 mA in the range of 2θ from 5 to 80°. Agilent ICP-OES 725 ES was used to determine the boron content of the catalyst. Prior to the measurement, the samples were pre-treated and dissolved in a mixture of nitric and hydrofluoric acids under heating conditions. The N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms of the catalyst samples were obtained on a Mac Tristar II 3020 Specific Surface Area and Pore Analyser and the specific surface area was calculated from the adsorption data using the Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) method at relative pressures in the range of 0.05–0.3. The Fourier Transform Infrared (FT-IR) spectra were recorded using a Bruker Tensor 27 spectrometer with a resolution of 4 cm−1. Thermal gravimetric analysis (TGA) was performed in air on a thermal analyzer (WCT-1D, Beiguang Hongyuan Instrument Co). The surface morphology of the catalyst samples was observed using a Talos F200X field emission scanning transmission electron microscope (TEM) from Thermo Fisher Scientific, USA, and the valence changes of the catalyst surface species were analysed using the company's K-Alpha X-ray photoelectron spectrometer (XPS), with standard Al Kα X-rays as the excitation source and an accelerating voltage of 1486.6 eV. C1s (284.6 eV) as an internal standard for charge correction of the measured elements. Raman spectra of catalyst samples were collected using a Renishaw in-situ laser confocal Raman spectrometer (inVia Qontor) with a 100x lens and an excitation wavelength of 532 nm. An AVANCE 3–400 M wide-cavity solid-state NMR spectrometer (Bruker, Switzerland) was used to characterise the catalyst transformation before and after the ODHP reaction. 3 Results 3.1 Catalytic performance The catalytic performance was evaluated using a fixed-bed quartz reactor system operating at atmospheric pressure, with reaction conditions (WHSV = 3.53 gC3H8·gcat−1·h−1, T = 620 °C) determined through prior optimization (Fig. S1). Subsequently, as shown in Fig. 1, distinct catalytic performances were observed by varying the loading content of B2O3 in the catalyst. As the B2O3 content increased, the conversion of propane rose, while the selectivity for propylene decreased; conversely, the selectivity for ethylene and methane increased. Generally, a higher conversion correlates with greater selectivity for ethylene, whereas propylene selectivity is higher at lower conversion levels. This trend aligns with the conclusions drawn in related studies of other boron-containing catalysts [29]. Surprisingly, as the loading of B2O3 and propane conversion increased, the selectivity for CO2 exhibited a decreasing trend, while the selectivity for CO gradually increased. This behavior contrasts with that observed in other metal oxide catalysts, where higher conversion typically correlates with increased CO2 selectivity [16–18]. Furthermore, when the B2O3 loading was increased to 50 wt%, a decrease in propane conversion was observed, accompanied by an increase in propylene selectivity. The observed phenomenon can be rationalized by considering the phase behavior of B2O3 at elevated temperatures. Excessive B2O3 loading (50 wt%) led to complete coverage of the catalyst support surface, effectively transforming the system into a B2O3-dominated composition. It was supposed that this composition undergoes a phase transition at ∼450 °C, resulting in viscous flow and substantial loss of the active component through volatilization, thereby accounting for the rapid catalyst deactivation observed during the reaction [23,31]. The carbon balance, calculated from GC analysis of all effluent components, consistently exceeded 95 % across the tested process (Fig. S2a). The catalytic performance was significantly influenced by the SiO2-TiO2 ratio in the support material. As shown in Fig. 2, systematic variation of the SiO2/TiO2 ratio revealed that propane conversion generally increased with higher TiO2 content, although a notable decrease occurred when prue TiO2 was employed. Importantly, carbon balances exceeded 95 % across all support compositions (Fig. S2b), confirming efficient carbon utilization throughout the reaction. Catalytic stability was evaluated over a 24-hour period for the synthesized catalysts ( Fig. 3). Extended reaction time in the ODHP process led to significant decreases in propane and oxygen conversion when pure SiO2 was employed as the support (Fig. 3 a-b), indicating rapid catalyst deactivation. Carbon balance calculations confirmed that this activity decline was not caused by coke deposition (Fig. S3). In contrast, catalyst stability showed progressive improvement with increasing TiO2 content in the support material. Optimal stability was achieved with pure TiO2 as the support, maintaining relatively constant propane conversion throughout the 24-hour ODHP reaction. Fig. 4 presents the product selectivity trends for catalysts with varying SiO2/TiO2 ratios during the ODHP process. As shown in Fig. 3 a, the propane conversion for B2O3/SiO2, B2O3/SiO2-TiO2 (2−1), and B2O3/SiO2-TiO2 (1−1) catalysts exhibited a significant decrease with increasing reaction time. This decline in conversion was accompanied by a gradual increase in propylene selectivity and a corresponding decrease in ethylene selectivity, as demonstrated in Fig. 4 a-c. These observations are consistent with previous studies on boron-containing catalysts, where the oxidative dehydrogenation pathway predominates at low conversion levels, while propane oxidative cracking becomes more favorable at higher conversion levels [3,26]. With increasing TiO2 content, the fluctuations in propylene and ethylene selectivity gradually diminished, as shown in Fig. 4 d-e. Fig. 4 f demonstrates a slight decrease in total olefin (C2 + C3) selectivity with reaction time for all catalyst samples. Although the pure TiO2-supported catalyst maintained high olefin selectivity after 24 hours of reaction, indicating superior stability, several limitations were identified. First, the catalytic activity of the pure TiO2 system was significantly lower compared to SiO2-containing catalysts. Second, experimental observations reveal that pure TiO2-supported catalysts tend to undergo particle pulverization during ODHP, which may impede their further application. To better understand these effects, additional experiments were performed to elucidate the individual roles of each component in the catalytic process. Bare B2O3 exhibited poor thermal stability due to its low melting point (∼450 °C), resulting in melting and subsequent flow within the quartz reactor at reaction temperatures. Upon cooling, the molten B2O3 solidified into a glassy phase at the reactor bottom, causing reactor blockage and reaction failure. In contrast, the catalytic performance of pure SiO2 and TiO2 at 620 °C is summarized in Table S1. The SiO2 sample was prepared through silica sol drying followed by calcination. A control experiment was conducted using an 'empty reactor' filled with quartz sand. Comparable catalytic performance was observed between the quartz sand-filled reactor and the pure SiO2 catalyst, with minor differences potentially arising from variations in SiO2 particle size distribution. Based on the obtained results, no definitive conclusions can be drawn regarding the catalytic contribution of SiO2 in the reaction system. 3.2 Characterization of catalysts H2-TPR analysis was performed to evaluate the redox properties of the catalysts ( Fig. 5). As shown in Fig. 5 a, catalysts with 10 wt% B2O3 loading exhibited two distinct reduction peaks: a primary peak at approximately 670 °C and a secondary, less intense peak at 800 °C. With increasing B2O3 loading, the temperature corresponding to the primary reduction peak progressively decreased, while the intensity of the secondary peak was significantly reduced. This shift in reduction behavior suggests enhanced reducibility and improved oxidative capacity of the catalysts. Subsequently, to investigate the support composition effect, catalysts with a fixed B2O3 loading (30 wt%) and varying SiO2/TiO2 ratios were systematically evaluated (Fig. 5 b). The H2-TPR profiles revealed similar redox behavior for most catalysts, except for the pure TiO2-supported sample. The oxidative capacity of the catalysts demonstrated a positive correlation with TiO2 content, consistent with the catalytic performance tests where a gradual enhancement in propane conversion was observed with increasing TiO2 content in the support material. O2-TPD analysis was performed to investigate the oxygen species distribution in the catalysts (Fig. S4). The desorption profiles were dominated by peaks corresponding to strongly bound lattice oxygen species [32], with negligible contributions from weakly adsorbed surface oxygen. This observation suggests limited surface area availability for oxygen adsorption. Furthermore, high-temperature calcination (> 600 °C) promoted the formation of more stable lattice oxygen species [32]. Catalysts supported on TiO2 exhibited more intense lattice oxygen desorption peaks compared to their SiO2-supported counterparts, suggesting enhanced oxygen mobility that could account for their superior catalytic activity. Comparative XRD analysis was performed on fresh and used catalysts (after 24 h ODHP reaction) supported on pure SiO2, pure TiO2, and SiO2-TiO2 (2:1) mixtures ( Fig. 6). It is evident that the XRD pattern of the SiO2-supported catalyst exhibited a major broad reflection due to the amorphous nature of the material [33]. Characteristic diffraction peaks of B2O3 were identified at 14.6° and 27.8° (ICDD: 00–006–0297). Additionally, the peaks at 23.1° and 26.8° correspond to B2SiO5 (ICDD: 00–042–0382). In the case of B2O3-SiO2 (ICDD: 00–042–0383), the characteristic peaks partially overlapped with those of the aforementioned two crystalline phases. When pure TiO2 was used as the carrier, in addition to the characteristic peaks of B2O3, the more prominent diffraction peaks were the characteristic peaks of the anatase phase (ICDD: 00–021–1272) located at 25.3°, 37.8° and 48.0°, and in addition the characteristic peaks located at 27.4° and 36.1° indicated the presence of the rutile phase (ICDD: 00–021–1276) [34]. The primary crystalline phase identified in the B2O3/SiO2-TiO2 catalyst through XRD analysis was a combination of crystalline phases from the two previous samples, exhibiting significant peak overlap. Due to the overlapping diffraction peaks, the formation of significant new crystalline phases could not be detected using XRD. Additionally, the XRD spectrum of h-BN, included as a control group (Fig. S5), was analyzed. After calcination, it is evident that the crystalline phase of h-BN is homogeneous, and its crystal structure is distinctly different from that of the B2O3/support. Following 24 hours of the ODHP reaction, the diffraction peak intensities of the B2O3/SiO2 and h-BN catalysts were significantly diminished, whereas the diffraction peak intensities of the other two catalysts remained largely unchanged. Furthermore, it can be observed that the diffraction peaks of the crystalline phase B2SiO5 at 23.1° and 26.8° on the fresh B2O3/SiO2 catalyst are significantly more intense than those on the used B2O3/SiO2 catalyst (these peaks are nearly absent in the latter’s spectrum). We speculate that the loss of the B2SiO5 crystalline phase during the ODHP process led to a weakening of the interaction between the boron species and the SiO2 support. Through analysis of the experimental results, it was found that the stability of the TiO2-supported catalyst is significantly superior to that of the pure SiO2-supported catalyst. In studies investigating the deactivation of boron-containing catalysts, the loss of boron species has been identified as one of the primary causes of deactivation [26,27,35]. Therefore, it is speculated that the formation of a composite structure between titanium species and boron species may inhibit the loss of boron species. However, after the introduction of TiO2, the XRD spectra did not reveal the formation of a distinct crystalline phase of the titanium-boron composite compound. This may be attributed to the overlapping of characteristic peaks from other crystalline phases, which obscured the relevant signals. Furthermore, the reason for the enhanced catalytic activity following the addition of TiO2 requires further investigation. Consequently, additional characterization of the catalysts was conducted to gain deeper insights into the mechanisms underlying the improved activity and stability resulting from the incorporation of TiO2. Based on the properties of the raw materials used for catalyst synthesis, it can be inferred that the pore structure of the catalysts is predominantly composed of interlayer pores, lacking a well-developed porous architecture. This was confirmed by the specific surface area of the catalysts calculated using the Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) method ( Table 1). The specific surface areas of several catalysts were remarkably low, particularly when pure SiO2 was employed as the support. Furthermore, it was observed that the specific surface area of the catalysts decreased after 24 hours of the ODHP reaction compared to that of the fresh catalysts, with this reduction being especially pronounced for the SiO2-containing catalysts. In conjunction with the previously observed stability performance of the catalysts, it is hypothesized that some alterations occurred on the surface of the SiO2-containing catalysts, which may also contribute to their rapid deactivation. To further investigate the reasons behind the changes in catalyst activity, thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) was performed on the aforementioned catalyst samples, as illustrated in Fig. S6. The weight loss observed below 200 °C was attributed to the desorption of H2O, while the catalyst samples exhibited continuous weight loss as the temperature increased. This loss was associated with the dehydration of the generated H3BO3 [27]. However, as the temperature further increased, no significant weight loss due to oxidative decomposition was observed for the catalyst samples within the reaction temperature range under an air atmosphere. This indicates that the catalysts demonstrated relatively good stability within this temperature range, allowing us to preliminarily rule out significant differences in catalyst performance caused by variations in thermal stability. On the other hand, unlike some boron-containing catalysts, whose thermogravimetric curves show a noticeable weight increase due to oxygen functionalization [23], such a phenomenon was not observed in this study. This provides preliminary evidence that the catalysts do not require an induction period. The overall structure of the catalyst samples was characterized using transmission electron microscopy (TEM). As shown in Fig. 7 a-b, the TEM images of the samples before and after the application of the B2O3/SiO2 catalyst are presented. In Fig. 7 b1, noticeable agglomeration and sintering phenomena were observed in the catalysts after 24 hours of the ODHP process. Additionally, Fig. 7 a2 and b2 reveal that the B2O3/SiO2 catalyst exhibits a distinct crystalline structure. Upon the incorporation of TiO2, significant changes in the catalyst morphology were observed (Fig. 7 c-f). By comparing the overall morphology of the catalyst before and after TiO2 doping, it was found that the introduction of TiO2 as a carrier led to a more ordered arrangement of boron species. After the catalyst underwent the ODHP process for 24 hours, the loss of boron species on the surface became evident, as shown in Fig. 7 d, where the underlying TiO2 carrier was partially exposed. To further investigate this phenomenon, the reaction time was extended, allowing for clearer observation. It was discovered that after catalyst deactivation, primarily only the carrier "framework" remained. Analysis of the residual boron species indicated that they were "embedded" within the TiO2 surface, forming a composite structure with titanium, as illustrated in Fig. 7 f-g. For comparison, TEM images of the B2O3/TiO2 catalyst were also included (Fig. S7), which exhibited a structure highly similar to that of B2O3/SiO2-TiO2. Based on these observations, it can be preliminarily inferred that the formation of this embedded composite structure inhibits the loss of active components, thereby contributing to the enhanced stability of the B2O3/SiO2 catalysts. Specifically, a significant interaction between boron and titanium appears to facilitate the formation of this composite structure [36]. Furthermore, regarding the rapid deactivation observed in catalysts with pure SiO2 as the carrier, it should be emphasized that the loss of active components is not the sole cause of catalyst deactivation. The agglomeration and sintering of the catalysts under reaction conditions must also be considered as primary contributing factors. This conclusion was supported by the notable changes in the specific surface area of the B2O3/SiO2 catalysts before and after the reaction. To gain deeper insights into the characteristics of the catalysts and the structural changes occurring before and after the reaction, the catalyst samples were analyzed using Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy (FT-IR) and X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) both prior to and following the reaction. The FT-IR spectra of the catalyst samples exhibited several distinct absorption peaks, as shown in Fig. 8. The stretching vibrational absorption peaks corresponding to B-OH (3215 cm−1) and B-O (1198 cm−1) were clearly observed [36]. These species are recognized as the active components of boron-containing catalysts in the ODHP process [37]. In this study, the fresh catalyst samples also displayed these two characteristic peaks. In contrast, studies on conventional boron-containing catalysts, such as h-BN catalysts, typically reveal these absorption peaks only after pre-activation. As a result, fresh h-BN catalysts are generally inert in ODHP [19], and their catalytic activity and olefin yield significantly improve only after additional activation. In the present work, it is evident that the induction period for the catalyst can be effectively circumvented. Furthermore, the spectrum of the B2O3/SiO2 catalyst exhibited a characteristic B-O-Si vibration band at 670 cm−1 [38], which underwent a blue shift to 648 cm−1 in the B2O3/SiO2-TiO2 system, indicating weakened B-O-Si interactions. Upon TiO2 incorporation, distinct Ti-O stretching vibrations emerged in the 760–850 cm−1 region [39], while the pure TiO2-supported catalyst displayed the characteristic broad absorption band of TiO2 between 400 and 800 cm−1 [40]. The XPS spectra of the catalyst samples are displayed in Fig. 9. As shown in Fig. 9 a, the B 1 s peak of the catalyst samples with SiO2-TiO2 mixed carriers exhibits a shift toward lower binding energy compared to those with pure SiO2 carriers, indicating the conversion of B2O3 to BOx/B-O species [23,24,41,42]. Additionally, no significant change was observed in the Si 2p peaks for both supports (Fig. 9 b). The O 1 s peaks of the samples remained largely unchanged, except for an increase in the Ti-O peaks (Fig. 9 c) [43]. To further investigate the interaction between boron and titanium, pure TiO2 calcined under identical conditions was included as a control group, and the Ti 2p spectra of the three samples were obtained (Fig. 9 d-f). The results reveal that the Ti3+ species content in the B2O3/SiO2-TiO2 sample is 8.78 %, while in the B2O3/TiO2 sample, it is 9.49 %. In contrast, the Ti3+ species content in pure TiO2 is only 3.97 %. This notable difference suggests that B2O3 promotes a specific interaction between TiO2 and boron species, likely leading to the formation of B-O-Ti bonds and the reduction of Ti4+ to a lower valence state. The Raman spectra of the B2O3/SiO2 and B2O3/SiO2-TiO2 catalysts are shown in Fig. 10. The B2O3/SiO2-TiO2 catalyst exhibits distinct Raman bands at 143 cm−1, 395 cm−1, 516 cm−1, and 639 cm−1, which are characteristic of anatase-dominated spectral features [44,45]. In contrast, the B2O3/SiO2 catalyst displays weaker peak intensities, with Raman bands observed at 209 cm−1 and 499 cm−1, attributed to lattice-translatory oscillations in boric acid and O-B-O bending vibrations, respectively [46]. Both catalysts show a peak at 881 cm−1, corresponding to the stretching vibration of B-O. The 11B solid-state NMR analysis of both fresh and used catalyst samples revealed that the one-dimensional 11B NMR spectra exhibited extensive overlapping signals due to quadrupolar interactions ( Fig. 11). Through the application of appropriate processing techniques, these signals were successfully identified [28,47,48], and the relevant parameters are summarized in Table S2. It was observed that the 11B spectra of the fresh B2O3/SiO2-TiO2 catalyst were predominantly dominated by tri-coordinated boron sites, with a relatively minor proportion of tetra-coordinated boron sites. The increase in B[3] a, along with changes in other B[3] species after 24 hours of the ODHP reaction, is attributed to dynamic conversions occurring under the reaction conditions [22]. Additionally, a slight increase in the amount of tetra-coordinated boron was detected in the used catalyst. Previous studies have indicated that the activity of boron-containing catalysts is primarily associated with tri-coordinated boron sites, whereas tetra-coordinated boron tends to be inactive [28,46,49]. Therefore, it can be concluded that the fresh B2O3/SiO2-TiO2 catalyst exhibits higher activity compared to its used counterpart. This phenomenon may explain the observed decrease in catalyst activity with prolonged reaction time or may result from a specific transformation of boron species within the catalyst during the initial stages of the ODHP reaction, which warrants further investigation in future studies. However, given the minimal increase in the amount of B[4] species, it is reasonable to conclude that the B2O3/SiO2-TiO2 catalyst demonstrates relatively stable catalytic performance throughout a 24-hour ODHP process. 4 Discussion 4.1 Role of TiO 2 in anchoring boron species The introduction of TiO2 into the support was found to play a crucial role in the ODHP process, as evidenced by the observed catalytic performance. Firstly, it significantly enhances the stability of the catalyst. Secondly, the addition of an appropriate amount of TiO2 improves the catalytic activity. To gain deeper insights into the role of TiO2 during the catalytic reaction, we prioritized an analysis of the primary causes of catalyst deactivation. In studies examining boron-containing catalysts for ODHP, the deactivation of these catalysts has been attributed to the loss of boron species, as confirmed by measuring the boron content before and after the reaction [27]. However, our observations indicate that the loss of boron species does not fully explain the deactivation behavior of the catalysts. This discrepancy arises because boron loss is expected to be a continuous process, whereas a significant body of research suggests that the catalysts can maintain consistently high activity over extended periods [23,27,33]. Clearly, although the loss of boron is the primary cause of catalyst deactivation, other factors also contribute to this process. As shown in Fig. 7 c, sintering phenomena were observed in the used B2O3/SiO2 catalysts, which also appear to have led to a significant decline in catalytic activity. Additionally, we compared the XPS B1s spectra of the catalyst samples before and after the reaction (Fig. S8). The B1s peaks of the catalysts before and after 24 hours of reaction showed no significant changes, indicating that the properties of the boron species remained stable throughout the reaction period, ruling out the possibility of stability being affected by changes in the nature of the boron species. The introduction of TiO2 induces a specific interaction between the TiO2 support and the active boron species. As illustrated in Fig. 7 k and Fig. 7 l, boron species are immobilized in an "embedded" form by TiO2. The encapsulation of metal nanoparticles within partially reduced oxide supports exhibits typical characteristics of strong metal-support interactions [50]. Specifically, nanoscale boron species partially nucleate at the interface of a deformed Ti region and may subsequently grow into composite structures, a phenomenon documented by Oghenevweta et al. [51]. We speculate that this composite structure effectively prevents the loss and agglomeration of active species. The boron content of catalyst samples before and after the reaction was quantified by ICP-OES (Table S3); this result, further corroborated by XPS-measured molar concentrations of boron atoms, conclusively demonstrates that TiO2 incorporation significantly mitigates boron species loss. After 24 hours of the ODHP reaction, only a minimal loss of boron species was observed in the TiO2-containing samples, in stark contrast to the samples with pure SiO2 as the support. Additionally, XRD analysis revealed that the fresh B2O3/SiO2 catalyst exhibits distinct B2SiO5 characteristic peaks, whereas these peaks disappear in the used B2O3/SiO2 catalyst, indicating a weakening of the interaction between B and Si. This weakening likely contributes to the easier loss of boron species in catalysts with pure SiO2 as the support. Furthermore, the changes in specific surface area of the catalysts before and after the reaction, calculated using the BET method, demonstrated that the TiO2-containing samples exhibit minimal changes in specific surface area. This appears to suggest that the incorporation of TiO2 may also suppress catalyst sintering. Fig. 9 a presents the B 1 s spectra of the B2O3/SiO2 and B2O3/SiO2-TiO2 catalysts. The data indicate that the addition of TiO2 shifts the B 1 s peak toward lower binding energy, confirming the transformation from B2O3 to BOx/B-O species [23,24,41,42]. Combined with the analysis of the Ti 2p spectra of the B2O3/SiO2-TiO2 catalysts and pure TiO2, it can be concluded that interactions similar to B-O-Ti indeed exist [50]. Furthermore, a comparison of the Ti 2p spectra of the B2O3/TiO2 and B2O3/SiO2-TiO2 catalysts (Fig. 9 d) reveals that the presence or absence of SiO2 in the support has no significant effect on the binding energy of the Ti 2p peak, thereby ruling out the possibility of interactions between Si and Ti. Catalytic performance tests demonstrate that the introduction of TiO2 into the support significantly improves the stability of the catalyst. Additionally, 11B solid-state NMR analysis shows no significant increase in B [4] species in the B2O3/SiO2-TiO2 catalyst before and after the reaction, further confirming its stable performance [28,46,49]. 4.2 Factors driving high catalytic performance Other boron-containing catalysts, such as h-BN catalysts or BOx/support catalysts synthesized using boric acid via the impregnation method, require an induction period to achieve oxygen functionalization on their surfaces [19,23,46]. This induction period enriches the catalyst surface with more active species, thereby enhancing catalytic activity [23]. In contrast, by directly selecting B2O3 as the feedstock and immobilizing it on the support, the induction period can be eliminated, allowing the fresh catalyst surface to inherently possess active species. This conclusion can be preliminarily drawn from our FT-IR analysis (Fig. 8). Furthermore, no increase in propane conversion was observed during the extended reaction period, and no weight gain trend due to oxygen functionalization was detected in the TGA curves (Fig. S6), which further supports this conclusion [26,27]. Catalytic performance tests demonstrated excellent activity, and 11B solid-state NMR analysis (Fig. 11) revealed that the fresh B2O3/SiO2-TiO2 catalyst contains a significant amount of B[3] species with only a minor proportion of B[4] species, providing a prerequisite for the high activity of the catalyst. After the introduction of TiO2 into the support, it was observed that the activity of TiO2-containing catalysts surpassed that of catalysts using pure SiO2 as the support. Love et al. noted in their study that pure SiO2 supports have a detrimental effect on the propylene selectivity of h-BN [46], which aligns with our findings. Studies on the PDH process have shown that TiO2 is prone to lattice oxygen consumption under the high-temperature reducing atmosphere characteristic of PDH [52]. This consumption, in turn, facilitates the cleavage of C-H bonds [53]. These studies provide valuable insights, prompting us to analyze the factors contributing to the enhanced catalytic activity from multiple perspectives. Firstly, as shown in Table S1, the control group using pure TiO2 as the catalyst exhibited a propane conversion of 25.3 %, which was higher than the 15.2 % conversion observed with pure SiO2 as the control group. In terms of oxygen conversion, the TiO2-only control group was able to nearly fully convert the oxygen in the feedstock gas, even at low propane conversion (Fig. S9). The increased oxygen consumption by TiO2 promotes forming an oxygen-deficient environment during the reaction. To some extent, a moderately oxygen-deficient environment can facilitate propane cracking, leading to more ethylene production [21,26,54]. Therefore, as the TiO2 content increases, we observe an increase in propane conversion within a specific range. The analysis of the O2-TPD results (Fig. S4) leads to the conclusion that the addition of TiO2 increases the amount of lattice oxygen in the catalyst. The gaseous oxygen in the feedstock replenishes the consumed lattice oxygen during the reaction, resulting in higher oxygen conversion. The trend curve ( Fig. 12 a) indicates that as the TiO2 content increases, propane conversion rises, ethylene selectivity improves, and propylene selectivity decreases. This observation confirms that the cracking reaction pathway is enhanced. As illustrated in Fig. 12 b, the selectivity of the cracking products, ethylene and methane, increases with propane conversion, a phenomenon that has been noted in related studies [29,55]. However, as the TiO2 content increases, the excess TiO2 may partially cover the active boron species on the catalyst surface, leading to a decrease in catalytic activity. More critically, the significant improvement in propane conversion following SiO2 incorporation stems principally from the formation of B-O-Si linkages (as confirmed by Fig. 8), which establish isolated, well-defined active sites. Complementary DFT calculations by Zhou et al. [26] reveal that these B-O-Si configurations enable Si-OH to construct hydrogen-bonding networks with neighboring B-OH groups, thereby synergistically activating both oxygen and propane molecules while simultaneously lowering the activation energy barrier. These findings demonstrate that SiO2 incorporation is essential for achieving optimal catalytic performance. On the other hand, pure TiO2-supported catalysts suffered from severe particle pulverization during ODHP reactions. The addition of SiO2 as a binding agent successfully suppressed this powdering phenomenon under operational conditions. Finally, the Raman spectra shown in Fig. 10 were locally magnified for closer examination ( Fig. 13). The magnified spectra reveal that the B2O3/SiO2 catalyst exhibits more pronounced Raman bands at 211 cm−1, 499 cm−1, and 882 cm−1, which are characteristic of boric acid. In contrast, the B2O3/SiO2-TiO2 catalyst displays a more prominent Raman band at 804 cm−1, corresponding to the symmetric breathing mode of six-membered boroxol rings, a characteristic peak of B2O3. In situ Raman spectroscopy analysis conducted by Love et al. demonstrated that the decline in the activity of the B/SiO2 catalyst is associated with the weakening of the characteristic band at this wavelength [46]. The increased intensity of the peaks at this location suggests that the catalyst may exhibit higher activity. Therefore, we conclude that the B2O3/SiO2 catalyst is more prone to the formation of metaborate species. Due to the flow characteristics of boric acid under reaction conditions, the active boron component is more readily lost [26,27], leading to a rapid decline in catalytic activity. This is also one of the reasons why the B2O3/SiO2 catalyst exhibits lower activity and a faster deactivation rate. 5 Conclusion To address the issues of low activity and poor stability in conventional boron-containing catalysts for the oxidative dehydrogenation of propane (ODHP), B2O3/SiO2-TiO2 catalysts were synthesized via a straightforward mechanical blending method. FT-IR analysis identified distinct B-OH and B-O absorption peaks, which are proposed to act as active sites in the ODHP process. By optimizing the carrier composition, the catalyst achieved a propane conversion of 60.8 % at 620 °C, with a total olefin selectivity of 70.2 % and an overall yield exceeding 40 %. These results demonstrate the significant catalytic activity of B2O3 as an active component in ODHP catalysts. Based on ICP-OES and TEM characterization, the primary deactivation mechanisms of the B2O3/SiO2 catalysts were identified as the loss of boron species and catalyst sintering. The incorporation of TiO2 significantly enhanced both the stability and activity of the catalyst. Further investigation into the role of TiO2 revealed that: (1) TEM and XPS analyses indicated potential interactions between TiO2 and boron species, suggesting that boron species may embed into the deformed TiO2 surface, thereby inhibiting their loss; (2) O2-TPD analysis demonstrated that a moderate amount of TiO2 could provide additional lattice oxygen, and the replenishment of lattice oxygen by feedstock oxygen during the reaction creates an oxygen-deficient environment, promoting the cracking pathway of propane and leading to higher propane conversion and selectivity toward cracking products; (3) Raman spectroscopy revealed that the B2O3/SiO2-TiO2 catalysts exhibited a more pronounced Raman band for B2O3, whereas the B2O3/SiO2 catalysts primarily contained metaborate species, explaining their lower activity and faster deactivation. However, excessive TiO2 loading reduced propane conversion, likely due to active site coverage. Pure TiO2 support exhibited the lowest activity, while optimal SiO2 incorporation enhanced performance through the formation of isolated B-O-Si active sites. coredata.dc:description: Conventional mixed metal oxide catalysts for oxidative dehydrogenation of propane (ODHP) often face challenges in balancing propane conversion and olefin selectivity. In contrast, boron-containing catalysts can achieve higher selectivity for olefins. In this study, B2O3/SiO2-TiO2 catalysts were prepared via mechanical mixing and calcination, demonstrating high activity in ODHP with propylene and ethylene as primary products. At 620 °C, propane conversion reached 60.8 %, with total olefin selectivity of 70.2 %. Unlike h-BN or BOx/carrier catalysts, B2O3 was directly used as both feedstock and active component, eliminating the need for an induction period. The mixed SiO2-TiO2 carrier anchored boron species on the TiO2 surface, reducing boron loss and enhancing stability compared to pure SiO2-supported catalysts. These results highlight the potential of B2O3/SiO2-TiO2 for efficient propane oxidative dehydrogenation to olefins.
